He represents strength and courage in battle.
sections.In the books:
In the ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' novels, the Warrior represents strength in battle. He is prayed to for courage and victory. He carries a sword.

A passage in the ''[[Seven-Pointed Star]]'' says that the Warrior gave strength to the arms of Hugor of the Hill's four-and-forty mighty sons.

With the [[Valyrian]] sword Blackfyre in hand [[Daemon Blackfyre]] was said to have fought like the Warrior himself.

While in a nameless village, [[Catelyn Stark]] prays in a sept is modest and has no statues of the Seven, only rough charcoal drawings to represent them. She asks the Warrior to keep [[Robb Stark|Robb]] strong and shield him in his battles.

In the [[House of the Undying]] [[Daenerys Targaryen|Dany]] said a quick prayer, begging the Warrior for courage and the [[Great Stallion|Dothraki horse god]] for strength.

When [[Tyrion Lannister|Tyrion]] chose Ser [[Arys Oakheart]] to go with [[Myrcella Baratheon]] to [[Dorne]], Ser Arys lit a candle to the Warrior in thanks.
